Comment 3: 
It's spelled out for composite literals because they are
an exception to the usual rule for &:

> The address-of operator & generates the address of its
> operand, which must be addressable, that is, either a
> variable, pointer indirection, or slice indexing operation;
> or a field selector of an addressable struct operand;
> or an array indexing operation of an addressable array.

& of composite literals is spelled out not to cover lifetime
but because &arbitrary-expr is not typically legal: &(1+2) etc.
It's all because &T{...} is not an address-of; it's a funny spelling
for what I wish we'd spelled (*T){...}.
